intro: Sasaella retropila, commonly known as the backward-petaled sasa, is a rare and unique plant species belonging to the Cyperaceae family. It is characterized by its distinctive floral structure, with petals that curve backward, a feature that sets it apart from other members of its genus. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as forest floors or wetlands, where it thrives in cool, humid conditions. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, often forming dense clumps that help it anchor in wet soil. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, Sasaella retropila is considered a sensitive indicator of undisturbed ecosystems.
